newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK post-handover government shrugs off Blair snub.
newsitem.headline: HK post-handover government shrugs off Blair snub.

text.p: Hong Kong's future government on Thursday shrugged off a snub by British Prime Minister Tony Blair, who has decided to boycott a ceremony to inaugurate the controversial post-handover legislature.

The swearing-in will be "a ceremony which will show that the executive branch, legislature and the judiciary are all taking office at the same time", said Rita Fan, president of the provisional legislature, which Britain has sharply denounced.
The plan to install the legislature promptly after the flag change, while international VIPs who came for the handover party are still in town, would not be changed, Fan said.

The United States earlier said it too would shun the inauguration, reflecting Western disapproval that the unelected chamber will replace a democratically-elected parliament at midnight on June 30, when China takes back Hong Kong after 156 years of British colonial rule.

Future Hong Kong leader Tung Chee-hwa, senior government officials and top judges will also be sworn in during the ceremony in the first few hours of July 1. The timing of the inauguration was decided by a China-backed committee.

Henry Tang, a member of Tung's post-handover inner council, said the provisional legislature must be part of the swearing-in as it was a formal event to transfer administrative powers to the new government.
The inauguration would not be affected by criticism from foreign countries, he said.
"It is an event that is a Chinese people's event and we will not be swayed by those who don't belong here," Tang said.

More than 4,000 guests invited by Britain and China are expected to witness a glitzy joint handover ceremony on the night of June 30, marking the end of Britain's once-sprawling empire in Asia and China's national shame.

Blair and VIPs from other countries that contest the legitimacy of the provisional legislature were put in a diplomatic bind by China's plans to swear in the unelected chamber at the same venue immediately after the handover.
Blair said on Wednesday he would attend the handover ceremony, but officials made clear he would leave before the provisional legislature is sworn in.
Heir to the throne Prince Charles and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook will also attend as Britain's top representatives.
Colonial Governor Chris Patten welcomed Blair's plan to attend but said he hoped China would back down on its plan to swear in the provisional legislature just after the handover.
But Patten said he had not urged any foreign leaders to boycott China's ceremony.
Political analyst Michael DeGolyer said discord between Beijing and London over Patten's democratic reforms had set the stage for the "awkward dispute" surrounding the ceremonies.

The handover would be a matter of "you have your party and I'll have mine", with any interaction between the British and Chinese kept as formal and ceremonial as possible, said DeGolyer, director of a long-term study on the transition based at Hong Kong's Baptist University.
China ended months of speculation on Wednesday by announcing President Jiang Zemin would lead its delegation, the first visit to the territory by a Chinese head of state.

Jiang will receive the territory of 6.4 million people from Prince Charles, then remain just long enough for the swearing-in of the new administration before flying home for China's own mammoth celebration on the streets of Beijing.

Premier Li Peng, scorned by many Hong Kong people as a "butcher of Beijing" for his perceived role in unleashing the 1989 military crackdown in China, and Vice-Premier Qian Qichen, as well as other top officials will accompany Jiang on the trip.
